variant.question: Grid convergence is

options.text: westerly for positions East of the grid datum meridian on the northern hemisphere.
easterly in all positions having easterly longitude.
easterly in all positions having westerly longitude.
easterly for positions East of the grid datum meridian on the northern hemisphere.

variant.question: If the CH = 220°, Variation = 12°E, Deviation = 2°W, what is the corresponding TH?
'Grid convergence' is

options.text: the difference in direction between Grid North and True North.
independent of longitude, depending only of latitude.
named easterly when Grid North appears to be East of True North.

Which statement is correct?

options.text: The aircraft has already passed the vertex.
The aircraft has not yet reached the vertex.
The aircraft is just passing the vertex.
The aircraft is following the rhumb line track of 091°.

The 'Equation of time'

options.text: states the difference in time of transit of the mean Sun and the apparent Sun any particular day.
is used when calculating the difference between UTC and LMT.
states the difference between celestial time an apparent time.
is used to calculate mean time when standard time is known.

variant.question: What is the time required to travel along the parallel of latitude 60° N between meridians 010° E and 030° W at a groundspeed of 480 kts?
What is the time required to travel along the parallel of latitude 60°N between meridians 010°E and 030°W at a groundspeed of 480 kt?

Two aircraft depart from the same location and at the same time. Both follow a rhumb line track on latitude 87°N but they are flying opposite directions. Aircraft A is flying to the east and its speed is 160 kts, and the B one is flying to the west with a speed of 120 kts. Time of departure is 06:00 UTC. At what time will they meet again?

Position A: 50°00.0'N, 138°30.0'W, ST in A: UTC -9 hours
Position B: 50°00.0'N, 175°45.0'E, ST in B: UTC +12 hours
Distance between A and B: 1 736 NM, 1 636 NAM
Average TWC 25 kt
An aircraft departs from Position A on February 4th at 0800 ST. Considering the above data, what is its date and time of arrival overhead Position B?

An aircraft is flying directly from A 55°N, 005°E to B 45°N, 055°W. At a certain moment in time the true track of the aircraft is 275°. The aircraft is on track and the track angle error is 0°.

Which statement about this situation is correct?

options.text: The aircraft is flying along the great circle from A to B and has not yet passed the vertex of this great circle.
The aircraft is flying along the great circle from A to B and has already passed the vertex of this great circle.
The aircraft is flying along the great circle from A to B and will not pass the vertex of this great circle as it is not situated on the leg A to B.
The aircraft is flying along the rhumb line from A to B and the true track angle of the rhumb line is 275°.

How does the convergence of any two meridians on the Earth change with varying latitude?

options.text: It changes as sine of latitude.
It changes as cosine of latitude.
It is of constant value and does not change with latitude.
It increases with decrease of latitude.

variant.question: An approximate equation for calculating the convergency between two meridians is:

options.text: convergency = Change of longitude × sin (mean latitude)
convergency = Change of longitude × cos lat x 60
convergency = Change of longitude × sin (mean longitude)
convergency = Change of longitude × cos (mean latitude)

An aircraft is flying from A (50°S, 040°W) to B (60°S, 050°W). The initial great circle track is 206°. What will be the rhumb line track when passing 045°W?
An aircraft follows a great circle in the Northern Hemisphere. As the aircraft continues beyond the point where the track is 270°(T), the great circle track angle will...

options.text: decrease and the latitude will decrease.
increase and the latitude will decrease.
decrease and the latitude will increase.
increase and the latitude will increase.

variant.question: An aircraft flies on the Northern Hemisphere following an easterly direction to a destination aerodrome with a higher latitude than the departure aerodrome. A straight line is plotted between the departure and destination aerodrome to determine the shortest ground distance and the desired track. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this flight?

options.text: Due to Earth convergency, the track direction will continuously increase during the flight.
As great circle tracks are plotted as straight lines, they do NOT have a changing track direction.
Due to the increase in latitude, the final track angle at the destination will be higher than at the departure.

fly a spiral and finally end up at the South Pole.

options.text: Your great circle track will change by 30° throughout the flight.
The convergency north of your position will be greater than 30°.
The convergency north of your position will be smaller than 30°.

options.text: The closer to the pole, the more a great circle equals a straight line.
Rhumb Lines are always concave to the nearest pole.
In mid-latitudes, a great circle is convex towards the nearest pole.
The distance of a straight line in NM is always longer than the distance of a great circle in NM.
